THE INDWELLING, by Tim LaHaye and Jerry B. Jenkins. (Tyndale, $22.99.) The seventh volume in a series about true believers who confront the Antichrist. (+)
CRADLE AND ALL, by James Patterson. (Little, Brown, $25.95.) A former nun turned private eye works on a case involving two virgins who become pregnant.
THE BLUEST EYE, by Toni Morrison. (Knopf, $15.) The story of an 11-year-old black girl -- pregnant by her father -- who prays for her eyes to turn blue.
*HARRY POTTER AND THE CHAMBER OF SECRETS, by J. K. Rowling. (Levine/Scholastic, $17.95.) A British boy finds trouble when he returns to a witchcraft school.
EASY PREY, by John Sandford. (Putnam, $25.95.) Lucas Davenport investigates the death of a model.
*HARRY POTTER AND THE PRISONER OF AZKABAN, by J. K. Rowling. (Levine/Scholastic, $19.95.) A British boy's life at a school for witchcraft is threatened.
BEFORE I SAY GOOD-BYE, by Mary Higgins Clark. (Simon & Schuster, $26.) A woman with ESP searches for the truth behind the death of her husband.
THE BRETHREN, by John Grisham. (Doubleday, $27.95.) Three former judges, doing time at a federal prison in Florida, concoct a mail scam that goes awry.
OH, THE PLACES YOU'LL GO! by Dr. Seuss. (Random House, $17.) Finding your way through life.
THE EMPTY CHAIR, by Jeffery Deaver. (Simon & Schuster, $25.) Forensic specialists pursue a disturbed teenage boy who abducted two young women.
HARRY POTTER AND THE SORCERER'S STONE, by J. K. Rowling. (Levine/Scholastic, $16.95.) A British boy finds his fortune attending a school for witchcraft.
ANIL'S GHOST, by Michael Ondaatje. (Knopf, $25.) A Sri Lankan woman who studied medicine abroad returns to examine the victims of her country's terror.
THE RUN, by Stuart Woods. (HarperCollins, $26.) A United States senator, campaigning for the presidency, becomes the target of dangerous clandestine forces.
STAR WARS: Rogue Planet, by Greg Bear. (Lucas/ Del Rey/Ballantine, $26.) Obi-Wan Kenobi and Anakin Skywalker are swept up in a world of deadly intrigue.
THE WEDDING, by Danielle Steel. (Delacorte, $26.95.) An entertainment lawyer makes plans to marry a New York writer in her parents' Bel Air home.
*STANDOFF, by Sandra Brown. (Warner, $19.95.) A television reporter finds herself protecting the runaway teenage daughter of a multimillionaire from Texas.

Nonfiction
FLAGS OF OUR FATHERS, by James Bradley with Ron Powers. (Bantam, $24.95.) The story of the six men who raised the flag at Iwo Jima, by the son of one of them.
TUESDAYS WITH MORRIE, by Mitch Albom. (Doubleday, $19.95.) The author tells of his weekly visits to his old college mentor, who was near death's door.
IN THE HEART OF THE SEA, by Nathaniel Philbrick. (Viking, $24.95.) The story of the whaleship Essex, whose disastrous fate would inspire Herman Melville.
ME TALK PRETTY ONE DAY, by David Sedaris. (Little, Brown, $22.95.) A collection of autobiographical comic essays by the author of ''Naked.''
FROM DAWN TO DECADENCE, by Jacques Barzun. (HarperCollins, $36.) A survey of 500 years of Western cultural life, from 1500 to the present.
THE GREATEST GENERATION, by Tom Brokaw. (Random House, $24.95.) The lives of men and women who came of age during the Depression and World War II.
NO SUCH THING AS A BAD DAY, by Hamilton Jordan. (Longstreet, $22.) A memoir by Jimmy Carter's chief of staff, who has survived three bouts with cancer.
IT'S NOT ABOUT THE BIKE, by Lance Armstrong with Sally Jenkins. (Putnam, $24.95.) A memoir by the Tour de France champion and cancer survivor.
PAYNE STEWART, by Tracey Stewart with Ken Abraham. (Broadman & Holman, $24.99.) A biography of the golfer who died in a plane crash in 1999, by his widow. (+)
THE CAMINO, by Shirley MacLaine. (Pocket, $24.95.) A ''journey of the spirit'' takes the actress from present-day Spain through past lives to the origin of the universe.
THE GREATEST GENERATION SPEAKs, by Tom Brokaw. (Random House, $19.95.) What the people who fought in World War II confided in letters to the author.
*THE MILLIONAIRE MIND, by Thomas J. Stanley. (Andrews McMeel, $26.95.) An analysis of the people who make up America's financial elite.
*'TIS, by Frank McCourt. (Scribner, $26.) An Irish immigrant gets used to life in America: a memoir.
*THE ART OF HAPPINESS, by the Dalai Lama and Howard C. Cutler. (Riverhead, $22.95.) What Buddhism and common sense tell us about everyday problems.
FAIR BALL, by Bob Costas. (Broadway, $21.95.) The sportscaster's critique of major league baseball.
*I KNOW JUST WHAT YOU MEAN, by Ellen Goodman and Patricia O'Brien. (Simon & Schuster, $25.) A look at the enduring bonds of friendship between women.

An asterisk (*) indicates that a book's sales are barely distinguishable from those of the book above. A dagger (+)indicates that some bookstores report receiving bulk orders. And Bear in Mind (Editors' choices of other recent books of particular interest)

AMERICAN PHARAOH. Mayor Richard J. Daley: His Battle for Chicago and the Nation, by Adam Cohen and Elizabeth Taylor. (Little, Brown, $26.95.) A life of a man many urban experts consider his city's savior, not just the Great Satan of the 1968 Democratic National Convention.

DIANA MOSLEY, by Jan Dalley. (Knopf, $27.50.) A straightforward biography of one of the fabulous Mitford sisters, one who crossed over from colorful to weird and made her life with Sir Oswald Mosley, the British fascist leader.

EXPERIENCE, by Martin Amis. (Talk Miramax/ Hyperion, $23.95.) The novelist's nonfictional coming-of-age narrative, dense with personal history, firm opinions, literary gossip, name-dropping, wild regret, activist dentistry and Amis's father, Kingsley Amis.

HALF A HEART, by Rosellen Brown. (Farrar, Straus & Giroux, $24.) Civil rights activist in the 1960's, prosperous householder in the 80's, this novel's white heroine, longing for wholeness, seeks out the black daughter she once ran out on.

JIM THE BOY, by Tony Earley. (Little, Brown, $23.95.) A first novel, a coming-of-age novel, a Southern novel -- and yet no monsters, no parental abuse, erotic turmoil or domestic dysfunction! This clear, balanced, understated book makes growing up seem somehow possible.

THE OBITUARY WRITER, by Porter Shreve. (Mariner/Houghton Mifflin, paper, $12.) A lean, noirish first novel about a very junior journalist who comes to know a widow whose male associates seem to keep disappearing.

PAPAL SIN: Structures of Deceit, by Garry Wills. (Doubleday, $25.) An argument, angry and sorrowful, by a Roman Catholic who thinks the concentration of authority in the pope has led to ever more lamentable cover-ups of mistakes and assertions of things that are not so.

SAM THE CAT: And Other Stories, by Matthew Klam. (Random House, $22.95.) A smart, absorbing story collection (the author's first) in which young men discover that the world is an impossible place, at least right now: ''Sex is never normal with anyone,'' as one of them puts it. ''It's bizarre. It's wiggly meats.''

VERTIGO, by W. G. Sebald. (New Directions, $23.95.) An unclassifiable, wholly original book whose author (German born, lives in England) reflects on ever-expanding chunks of European history to examine his own origins and inner life.

WHAT I THINK I DID: A Season of Survival in Two Acts, by Larry Woiwode. (Basic Books, $25.) A memoir of two worlds, murderously blizzard-prone North Dakota and aspiring, literary New York, connected by the author's presence in both and by a series of religious experiences.
